revision.text:
{{globalize/US|date=July 2015}}
[[File:Cali - Arroyo Grande - Walker Co - Buckskin Girl Poster.jpg|thumb|250px|Example of a poster detailing information about unidentified victims, such as the [[Murder of Tammy Alexander|Caledonia Jane Doe]] (identified in 2015), [[Arroyo Grande Jane Doe]], [[Walker County Jane Doe]] and [[Buckskin Girl]], now identified as [[Murder of Marcia King|Marcia King]]]]
'''Unidentified decedent''' or '''unidentified person''' (also abbreviated as '''UID''' or '''UP''') is a term in [[American English]] used to describe a corpse of a person whose identity cannot be established by police and medical examiners. In many cases, it is several years before the identities of some UIDs are found, while in some cases, they are never identified.<ref>{{cite web|title=Resolved Cases|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/identifiedindex.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=18 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022035042/http://www.doenetwork.org/identifiedindex.html|archivedate=22 October 2014|df=}}</ref> A UID may remain unidentified due to lack of evidence as well as absence of personal identification such as a driver's license. Where the remains have deteriorated or been mutilated to the point that the body is not easily recognized, a UID's face may be [[forensic facial reconstruction|reconstructed]] to show what it had looked like before death.<ref>{{cite news|first= Ellen L.|last=Slott|title=Sculptor Reconstructs Faces to Aid Police|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/61189146/?terms=unidentified+murder+victim|newspaper=The Evening Review|date=21 December 1977|page=3|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = 21 July 2014 }} {{Open access}}</ref> UIDs are often referred to by the [[placeholder name]]s "John Doe" or "Jane Doe".<ref>{{cite web|title=Why Are Unidentified People Called John or Jane Doe?|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/29996/why-are-unidentified-people-called-john-or-jane-doe|website=mentalfloss.com|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref>
==Causes==
There are approximately 40,000 UIDs in the United States,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sullivan|first1=John|title=Missing/inaction Morgues hold about 40,000 sets of unidentified remains. Why isn't there a national database to help families find loved ones?|url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-03-06/news/25414943_1_web-site-unidentified-bodies-web-page|website=Philly.com|accessdate=4 January 2015|date=6 March 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About NamUs|url=http://www.namus.gov/about.htm|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The statistic stopped me in my tracks|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/htdocs/pdf/021609_erin.pdf|publisher=CBS|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref> and numerous others elsewhere.<ref>{{cite web|title=Unidentified Persons Geographic Index - International|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases-int/uid-geo-index-int.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref> A body may go unidentified due to death in a state where the person was unrecorded, an advanced state of decomposition or major facial injuries.<ref name="Mummies of the World"/> In many cases in the United States, teenagers with a history of running away would be removed from missing person files when they would turn 18, thus eliminating potential matches with existing unidentified person listings.<ref>{{cite news|title=New push to ID teen victim of 1977 murder|url=http://www.king5.com/article/news/local/investigations/new-push-to-id-teen-victim-of-1977-murder/281-307841378|accessdate=30 January 2018|work=King 5|agency=King TV|date=8 October 2013}}</ref>
===Location===
[[File:Jock Doe.jpg|thumb|150px|"Jock Doe," one of the [[Sumter County Does]], may have been from Canada but was found in the United States]]
Some UIDs die outside their native state. The [[Sumter County Does]], murdered in South Carolina, may have been Canadian.<ref name=bodies/> [[Death of Barbara Precht|Barbara Hess Precht]] died in Ohio in 2006 but was not identified until 2014. She had been living as a transient with her husband in California for decades but returned to her native state of Ohio, where she died of unknown circumstances.<ref name=new>{{cite news|last1=Dixon|first1=Deb|title=New Clues about 'Pearl Lady's' Husband|url=http://www.local12.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/new-clues-pearl-ladys-husband-20609.shtml|accessdate=20 November 2014|work=WKRC Cincinnati|agency=CBS|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141119034054/http://www.local12.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/new-clues-pearl-ladys-husband-20609.shtml|archivedate=19 November 2014|df=}}</ref> In both of these cases, the UIDs were found in a recognizable state and had their fingerprints and dental records taken with ease. It is unknown if the Sumter County Does' DNA was later recovered, since their bodies would require exhumation to recover DNA.<ref name=bodies>{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Bodies Remain Unidentified|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/53605031/|accessdate=7 August 2014|agency=The Daily Times-News|date=19 September 1976|page=10}}{{open access}}</ref> In Lourdes, France, a corpse believed to have been native to a different country was discovered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Case File 354UFFRA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases-int/354uffra.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=6 March 2015|date=30 April 2012}}</ref> Many illegal immigrants that die in the United States after crossing the border from Mexico remain unidentified.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stryker|first1=Ace|title=In Southwest, illegal immigrants often die anonymously|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/nation-world/article/In-Southwest-illegal-immigrants-often-die-1653188.php|accessdate=23 July 2015|work=Seattle Pi|publisher=''Associated Press''|date=2 April 2008}}</ref>
===Decomposition===
Many UIDs are found long after they die and have decomposed severely. This significantly changes their facial features and may prevent identification through fingerprints. Environmental conditions often are a major factor in decomposition, as some UIDs are found months after death with little decomposition if their bodies are placed in cold areas. Some are found in warm areas shortly after death, but hot temperatures and scavenging animals deteriorated the features.<ref name="Mummies of the World"/><ref>{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 10566|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/10566|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 22, 2014|date=August 27, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pima Arizona Jane Doe April 1981|url=http://canyouidentifyme.org/PimaArizonaJaneDoeApril1981|website=canyouidentifyme.org|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref> In some cases, warm temperatures mummify the corpse, which also distorts its features, though the tissues have survived initial decomposition. One example is the "[[Persian Princess]]", who died in the 1990s but, in an act of [[archaeological forgery]], was untruthfully stated in Pakistan to have been over 2,000 years old.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Romey |first= Kristin M. |last2= Rose |first2= Mark |date=January–February 2001 |url= http://www.archaeology.org/0101/etc/persia.html |title= Special Report: Saga of the Persian Princess |journal= Archaeology |volume= 54 |issue= 1 |publisher= Archaeological Institute of America|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> A man found in Idar-Oberstein, Germany, in 1994 had died months before his body was found, yet in some places, his skin had not deteriorated and tattoos were found, which are also used to identify the dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Case File 197UMDEU|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases-int/197umdeu.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref>
====Putrefaction====
[[Putrefaction]] often occurs when bacteria decompose the remains and generate gasses inside, causing the corpse to swell and become discolored.<ref name="Mummies of the World"/> In cases such as the Rogers family, who were murdered in 1989 by [[Oba Chandler]], the bodies were deposited in water but surfaced after gasses in their remains caused them to float to the surface. They were deceased a short period of time but were already severely decomposed and unrecognizable, due to putrefaction that occurred while underwater and high temperatures. It was not until a week later that dental records revealed their identities.<ref>Bourdett, Paul, prod. "Water Logged." ''[[Forensic Files]]''. Dir. Michael Jordan. HLN. 10 Dec. 2010. Television</ref>
====Skeletonization====
Skeletonization occurs when the UID has decayed to the point that bones and possibly some tissues are all that is found, usually when death occurred a significant amount of time before discovery. If a skeletonized body is found, fingerprints and toeprints are impossible to recover, unless they have survived the initial decomposition of the remains. Fingerprints are often used to identify the dead and were used widely before DNA comparison was possible.<ref name="Mummies of the World"/> In some cases, partial remains limit the available information; for example, a woman's skull found in Frankfurt, Germany, was insufficient to estimate her height and weight.<ref>{{cite web|title=Case File 469UFDEU|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases-int/469ufdeu.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref>
Skeletonized UIDs are often [[forensic facial reconstruction|forensically reconstructed]] if searching dental records and DNA databases is unsuccessful.
===Traumatic injuries===
Some UIDs experience trauma that significantly alters their appearance, especially those who die in vehicular accidents or were murdered in a violent manner. A facial expression often represents the pain, which shifts the face into a position that would not commonly be seen by the public, including those who have seen the person when they were alive. A body found decapitated would also prove to be unrecognizable.<ref name=role/> Many UIDs whose heads were not recovered remain unidentified, like in the [[Whitehall Mystery]], which occurred in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Whitehall Mystery|url=http://www.futilitycloset.com/2007/10/16/the-whitehall-mystery/|website=www.futilitycloset.com|accessdate=22 February 2015|date=16 October 2007}}</ref>
===Burning=== Often, someone who tries to conceal a body attempts to destroy it or render it unrecognizable.<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|last1=Hayes|first1=Ashley|title=How authorities identify a burned body|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/13/health/burned-body-id/|accessdate=1 January 2015|agency=[[CNN]]|date=13 February 2013}}</ref> The currently unidentified [[Yermo John Doe]] was killed approximately one hour before he was found, but was completely unrecognizable.<ref>{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 918|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/918|work=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=19 November 2014|date=12 March 2008}}</ref> When Lynn Breeden, a Canadian model, was murdered and set ablaze in a dumpster, her body was so severely damaged that DNA processing and fingerprint analysis were impossible. She was identified sometime later after her unique dentition matched her own dental records, and DNA extracted from her blood at a different scene was matched.<ref>Dowling, Paul. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gXHi3N9NjWA Charred Remains]." ''Forensic Files'' HLN. Atlanta, Georgia, 13 Nov. 1997. Television.</ref> [[Linda Agostini]]'s body was found burned near Albury, Australia in 1934. Her remains were identified ten years later through dental comparison.<ref name=adb>{{Citation| first=Bruce| last=Pennay| title =Agostini, Linda (1905 - 1934)| publisher =[[Australian National University]]| work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]| url =http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A130703b.htm| accessdate = 2007-05-02}}</ref>
==Identification process==
Usually, bodies are identified by comparing their usually unique [[DNA]], fingerprints and dental characteristics.<ref name=idvic>{{cite web|last1=Claridge|first1=Jack|title=Identifying the Victim|url=http://www.exploreforensics.co.uk/identifying-the-victim.html|website=Explore Forensics|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=10 December 2014}}</ref> DNA is considered the most accurate, but was not as widely used until the 1990s. It is often obtained through hair follicles, blood, tissue and other biological material.<ref name=eight>{{cite web|title=8 Body Parts Forensic Scientists Use to ID a Body|url=http://www.forensicsciencetechnician.org/8-body-parts-forensic-scientists-use-to-id-a-body/|website=Forensic Science Technician|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=2015}}</ref> Bodies can also be identified with other physical information, such as illnesses, evidence of surgery, breaks and fractures, and height and weight information.<ref name=three>{{cite web|last1=Valk|first1=Diana|title=3 Ways to Identify a Body When DNA is Not An Option|url=http://forensicoutreach.com/three-ways-to-identify-a-body-when-dna-is-not-an-option/|website=Forensics Outreach|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=18 November 2013}}</ref> A medical examiner will often be involved with identifying a body.<ref name=virtual>{{cite web|title=IDENTIFICATION PROCESS|url=http://www.sfu.museum/forensics/eng/pg_media-media_pg/identification/|website=virtualmuseum.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=lib>{{cite web|title=POSTMORTEM IDENTIFICATION|url=http://www.crimemuseum.org/crime-library/postmortem-identification|website=Crime Library|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=2014}}</ref>
===Mortuary photographs===
{{Double image|right|Valentine Doe body.jpg|150|Valentine Doe 1993 Comp.jpg|190|Reconstructions are considered to be more accurate with representing a UID when they were alive, especially with violent deaths, like "[[Valentine Doe]]"}}
Many police departments and medical examiners have made efforts to identify the deceased by placing mortuary photographs of the UID's face online. In some instances, the mortuary photographs would be retouched of wounds if they are to be released to the public.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Friess|first1=Steve|title=To identify 'John Doe' victims, investigators turn to the Web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/01/25/to_identify_john_doe_victims_investigators_turn_to_the_web/|accessdate=23 July 2015|work=Boston Globe|date=25 January 2004}}</ref> Dismembered corpses may also be digitally altered to appear attached to the body.<ref name=role>{{cite journal|last1=Pravir Bodkha, Bishwanath Yadav|title=A Role of Digital Imaging in Identification of Unidentified Bodies|journal=J Indian Acad Forensic Med|date=December 2012|volume=34|issue=4|accessdate=31 December 2014|url=http://medind.nic.in/jal/t12/i4/jalt12i4p318.pdf|issn=0971-0973}}</ref> This is not considered to be the most effective method, as the nature of death often distorts the UID's face.<ref>{{cite web|title=Question: Why don't you share photos from the coroner's office?|url=https://www.facebook.com/HelpIDMe/photos/a.830100223684553.1073741890.698376120190298/830098297018079/?type=1&theater|website=Help ID Me|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=9 April 2015|date=7 May 2014}}</ref> An example of this is that of "[[Grateful Doe]]," who was killed in a vehicular crash in 1995. He sustained extreme trauma that disfigured his face.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lohr|first1=David|title=Grateful Dead Fan Remains Nameless, 18 Years After Fatal Crash|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/25/grateful-doe_n_5208512.html|accessdate=5 September 2014|agency=[[Huffington Post]]|date=25 April 2014}}</ref>
A [[Milwaukee County Jane Doe|Jane Doe found in a river]] in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, had died months earlier, but was preserved by the cold temperatures. Her morgue photographs were displayed publicly on a medical examiner's website, but her face had been distorted by swelling after absorbing water, with additional decomposition.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Luthern|first1=Ashley|title=Investigators trying to solve mystery of woman found in 1982|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/investigators-trying-to-solve-mystery-of-woman-found-in-1982-b99396464z1-284101131.html?ipad=y|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|agency=Journal Sentinel|date=27 November 2014}}</ref>
Death masks have also been used to assist with identification, which have been stated to be more accurate, as they are required to display "relaxed expressions," which often do not illustrate the faces of the UIDs as they were found, such as that of [[L'Inconnue de la Seine]], a French suicide victim found in the late 1800s.<ref>{{cite news |first=Angelique|last=Chrisafis |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Ophelia of the Seine |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/art/visualart/story/0,,2219993,00.html |work=The Guardian Weekend magazine, page 17 - 27 |publisher=The Guardian |date= December 1, 2007 |accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref> However, a death mask will still depict sunken eyes or other characteristics of a long-term illness, which do not often show how they would have looked in life.<ref name="Mummies of the World">Madea, Burkhard, Johanna Preuss, and Frank Musshoff. "From Flourishing Life to Dust-The Natural Cycle." ''Mummies of the World''. Ed. Alfried Wieczorek and Wilfried Rosendahl. First ed. 2010. 28. Print.</ref>
===Reconstructions===
{{main article|Forensic facial reconstruction}}
When a body is found in an advanced state of decomposition or has died violently, reconstructions are sometimes required to receive assistance from the public, when releasing images of a corpse is considered taboo.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Izadi|first1=Elahe|title=Can this computer generated image of a ‘Baby Doe’ lead investigators to her identity?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/07/08/can-this-computer-generated-image-of-a-baby-doe-lead-investigators-to-her-identity/|accessdate=4 August 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=9 July 2015}}</ref> Often, those in a recognizable state will often be reconstructed due to the same reason.
Faces can be reconstructed with a three-dimensional model or by 2D, which includes sketches or digital reconstructions, similar to [[facial composite]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kilgannon|first1=Corey|title=Through Art and Forensics, Faces of Unidentified Victims Emerge|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/21/nyregion/through-art-and-forensics-students-give-unknown-victims-an-identity.html?smid=fb-share|accessdate=21 January 2015|work=New York Times|date=20 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= Rick|last= Martinez|title=Sculptor Reconstructs Faces to Aid Police|url=https://www.newspapers.com/search/#query=unidentified+murder+victim&offset=1|newspaper=San Bernardo County Sun|date=9 May 1979|page=27|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = 21 July 2014 }} {{Open access}}</ref>
Sketches have been used in a variety of cases. Forensic artist [[Karen T. Taylor]] created her own method during the 1980s, which involved much more precise techniques, such as estimating locations and sizes of the features of a skull. This method has been shown to be fairly successful.<ref>Dowling, Paul. "Saving Face." ''[[Forensic Files]]''. Prod. Paul Bourdett and Vince Sherry. Dir. Michael Jordan. 28 Nov. 2007.</ref>
The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children has developed methods to estimate the likenesses of the faces of UIDs whose remains were too deteriorated to create a two-dimensional sketch or reconstruction due to the lack of tissue on the bones. A skull would be placed through a CT scanner and the image would then be manipulated with a software that was intended for architecture design, to add digital layers of tissue based on the UID's age, sex and race.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicks|first1=Brad|title=Unraveling the Jane Doe Mystery|url=http://fox6now.com/2012/02/29/unraveling-the-jane-doe-mystery/|accessdate=25 July 2014|publisher=Fox News|date=29 February 2012}}</ref>
====Examples====
The following gallery depicts various ways UIDs have been reconstructed. None of those shown have been identified.
<gallery> File:Broward John Doe 79 (2).JPG|Forensic sketch ([[Broward County John Doe (1979)]]) File:East Haven Jane Doe.jpg|Reconstruction created with compiled photographs of facial features, a method known as IdentiKit ([[New Haven County Jane Doe]]) File:L'inconnue de la Seine (masque mortuaire).jpg|Death mask ([[L'inconnue de la Seine]]) File:Caroline County John Doe (older).jpg|Three dimensional clay reconstruction ([[Caroline County John Does|Caroline County John Doe]]) File:1980 FL John Doe.jpg|Facial composite ([[Pinellas County John Doe]]) File:Lumberton Jane Doe Recon 001c.jpg|Reconstruction created through a CT scan ([[Lumberton Jane Doe]]) </gallery>
===Problems===
In some cases, such as that of [[Christopher Wilder|Colleen Orsborn]], the true identity of the unidentified person is excluded from the case. In Orsborn's case, she had fractured one of the bones in her leg, but a medical examiner who performed the autopsy on her remains was not able to discover evidence of the injury and subsequently excluded her from the case. It was not until 2011 when DNA confirmed Orsborn was the victim found in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|title=Resolved Case|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/identifiedindex.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=28 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022035042/http://www.doenetwork.org/identifiedindex.html|archivedate=22 October 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Prieto|first1=Bianca|title=Dr. G links body found in Orange in 1984 to missing Daytona Beach teen girl|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-02-02/news/os-colleen-orsborn-body-missing-teen-20110202_1_dna-discovery-cold-cases-serial-killer|accessdate=28 December 2014|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=2 February 2011}}</ref> In cases such as the [[Racine County Jane Doe]], a rule out has also been subjected to criticism. Aundria Bowman, a teen who disappeared in 1989 who bore a strong resemblance to a body found in 1999, was excluded, according to the [[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]].<ref>{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4741|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/4741|website=NamUs.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=11 June 2014}}</ref> On an online forum, known as [[Websleuths]], users have disagreed with this ruling.<ref>{{cite web|title=WI - Raymond (Racine County) - WhtFem 199UFWI, 14-25, July'99 *Graphic*|url=http://www.websleuths.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-65381-p-2.html|website=websleuths.com|accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref> In the case of [[Lavender Doe]], a mother of a missing girl also disagreed with the exclusion of her missing daughter through DNA, as she claimed the reconstruction of the victim looked very similar to her daughter.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sutton|first1=Field|title=Brandi Well's mother reacts to Jane Doe renderings: "That looks so much like Brandi"|url=http://www.cbs19.tv/story/24697881/brandi-wells-mother-reacts-to-jane-doe-renderings|accessdate=31 July 2014|agency=[[KNOR|KTYX]] News|publisher=CBS|date=11 February 2014}}</ref>
==Notable cases==
===Unidentified=== {{Further|List of unidentified decedents in the United States|List of unidentified murder victims in the United States}} [[File:SomertonMan2.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Tamam Shud case]] includes a man who was found in 1948 in Adelaide, South Australia.]]
*[[Whitehall Mystery]], England, unidentified since 1888<ref name=c95>Cullen, Tom (1965) ''Autumn of Terror'', London: The Bodley Head, p. 95</ref> *[[Tamam Shud case]], Australia, unidentified since 1948<ref name=editorial>''The Advertiser'', [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page2654191 "Tamam Shud"], 10 June 1949, p. 2</ref> *[[Isdal Woman]], Norway, unidentified since 1970<ref>{{cite web|title=The Isdal Woman|url=http://www.futilitycloset.com/2014/01/03/the-isdal-woman/|website=[[Futility Closet]]|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> *[[Sumter County Does]], United States, unidentified since 1976<ref name=list>{{cite web|last=Warder|first=Robin|title=10 Mysterious Cases Involving Unidentified People|url=http://listverse.com/2013/06/14/10-mysterious-cases-involving-unidentified-people/|accessdate=8 April 2014|date=14 June 2013}}</ref> *"[[Beth Doe]]", United States, unidentified since 1976<ref name=dis>{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Dismembered body was girl who died of strangulation|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365013|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Evening Times|date=23 December 1976}}{{open access}}</ref> *[[Orange Socks]], United States, unidentified since 1979<ref name=may>{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|last1=Verhovek|first1=Sam Howe|title=Death-row Inmate May Not Deserve Penalty|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=847470|accessdate=11 October 2014|work=Indiana Gazette|date=8 January 1992|page=4}}{{open access}}</ref> *[[Persian Princess]], Pakistan, unidentified since 1996<ref name=archaeology>{{cite journal |last= Romey |first= Kristin M. |last2= Rose |first2= Mark |date=January–February 2001 |url= http://www.archaeology.org/0101/etc/persia.html |title= Special Report: Saga of the Persian Princess |journal= Archaeology |volume= 54 |issue= 1 |publisher= Archaeological Institute of America}}</ref>
===Formerly unidentified=== *[[List of formerly unidentified decedents]] *"Pyjama Girl", murdered in 1934 in Australia and identified in 1944 as [[Linda Agostini]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Agostini, Linda (1905–1934)|year=1993|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/agostini-linda-9966|work=Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> *"Tent Girl", murdered in 1968 and identified as [[Barbara Ann Hackmann Taylor]] in 1998<ref name="wolfe">Wolfe, Charles. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19980423&id=9PEaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=20cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6796,2875583 "Thirty years later, 'Tent Girl' homicide victim identified"], ''Daily News'', Bowling Green, Kentucky, 23 April 1998. Retrieved on 24 August 2014</ref> *"Precious Doe", murdered in 2001 and identified as [[Murder of Erica Green|Erica Michelle Green]] in 2005<ref>{{cite news|title=Charges In 'Precious Doe' Case|publisher=CBS Broadcasting|date=5 May 2005|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/05/05/national/main693165.shtml|accessdate=30 June 2006}}</ref> *"[[Ballarat Bandit]]", committed suicide in 2004 and identified as a Canadian man, George Robert Johnston in 2006<ref name=Province>{{cite web|work=The Vancouver Province|title=He told me, 'One day I'm going to do something big.' I Guess He Did|url=http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/unwind/story.html?id=d91e8e63-15d3-4609-b1e5-34ae1e7a0370|publisher=CanWest MediaWorks Publications|accessdate=28 April 2012|year=2006}}</ref> *"Baby Grace", murdered in 2007 and identified as [[Riley Ann Sawyers]] later that year<ref>{{cite news|title=DNA test confirms Riley is Baby Grace|work=Houston Chronicle|date=30 November 2007|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/DNA-test-confirms-Riley-is-Baby-Grace-1800537.php|accessdate=21 December 2014}}</ref> *"DuPage Johnny Doe", murdered in 2005 and identified as [[Murder of Atcel Olmedo|Atcel Olmedo]] in 2011<ref>{{cite news|title=Break In Case Of Unknown Child Found Dead Five Years Ago|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2011/02/18/naperville-boy-may-be-identified-5-years-later/|accessdate=12 November 2014|work=CBS Local|publisher=CBS|date=18 February 2011}}</ref> *"Baby Hope", murdered in 1991 and identified as [[Murder of Anjelica Castillo|Anjelica Castillo]] in 2013<ref name=report>{{cite news|title=Report: 'Baby Hope's' Real Name Revealed 22 Years After Body Found|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/10/10/baby-hopes-real-name-revealed-22-years-after-body-found/|accessdate=10 September 2014|agency=CBS New York|publisher=CBS|date=10 October 2013}}</ref> *"Pearl Lady", found in the [[Ohio River]] in 2006 and identified as [[Death of Barbara Precht|Barbara Precht]] in 2014<ref name=mm>{{cite news|last1=Dixon|first1=Deb|title=A mystery mother's identity revealed|url=http://www.local12.com/template/cgi-bin/archived.pl?type=basic&file=/news/features/top-stories/stories/archive/2014/10/wR7IVeo5.xml#.VG0_vfnF_Tp|accessdate=20 November 2014|work=WKRC Cincinnati|agency=12 WKRC-TV|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129184329/http://www.local12.com/template/cgi-bin/archived.pl?type=basic&file=%2Fnews%2Ffeatures%2Ftop-stories%2Fstories%2Farchive%2F2014%2F10%2FwR7IVeo5.xml#.VG0_vfnF_Tp|archivedate=29 November 2014|df=}}</ref> *Caledonia Jane Doe, found murdered in 1979 and identified in 2015 as [[Murder of Tammy Alexander|Tammy Alexander]]<ref name=dem>{{cite news|title=Police ID 'Jane Doe' found in Livingston Co. cornfield in 1979|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/01/26/jane-doe-caledonia/22342077/|accessdate=26 January 2015|date=26 January 2015}}</ref> *"Grateful Doe", died in a car accident in 1995 and identified in 2015 as [[Death of Jason Callahan|Jason Callahan]] <ref>{{cite news|title=DNA identifies ‘Grateful Doe’ as missing Myrtle Beach man 20 years after disappearance|url=http://wbtw.com/2015/12/09/dna-identifies-grateful-doe-as-missing-myrtle-beach-man-20-years-after-disappearance/|accessdate=9 December 2015|date=9 December 2015}}</ref> *"Buckskin Girl, found murdered in 1981 and identified as [[Murder of Marcia King|Marcia King]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title=Miami County Sheriff’s Office identifies 1981 cold case victim|url=https://www.daytondailynews.com/news/local/miami-county-sheriff-office-release-new-details-1981-unsolved-homicide-case/fmfdENjXMReEHV5VZGPcpI/|accessdate=11 April 2018|date=20 April 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of formerly unidentified decedents]] *[[List of unidentified decedents in the United States]] **[[List of unidentified murder victims in the United States]] *[[Body identification]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2015}}
'''Unitary theories of memory''' are hypotheses that attempt to unify mechanisms of [[short-term memory|short-term]] and [[long-term memory]]. James Nairne proposed the first unitary theory, which criticized [[Alan Baddeley|Alan Baddeley's]] [[working memory|working memory model]],<ref name=a>Nairne, J. (1990) A feature model of immediate memory. ''Memory & Cognition'' 18 (3), 251-269</ref> which is the dominant theory of the functions of short-term memory. Other theories since Nairne have been proposed; they highlight alternative mechanisms that the working memory model initially overlooked.
==Background==
===Overview===
{{Main|Working memory}}
'''Working memory''' is the system that is responsible for the transient holding and processing of new and already stored information, an important process for reasoning, comprehension, learning and memory updating. Working memory is generally used synonymously with [[short term memory]], but this depends on how the two forms of memory are defined.<ref name="Cowan">{{cite journal | title = What are the differences between long-term, short-term, and working memory? | author=Cowan, Nelson | journal=Prog Brain Res. | year=2008 | issue=169 | pages=323–338 |pmid=18394484 | doi=10.1016/S0079-6123(07)00020-9 | pmc=2657600 | volume=169}}</ref> Working memory includes subsystems that store and manipulate visual images or verbal information, as well as a central executive that coordinates the subsystems. It includes visual representation of the possible moves, and awareness of the flow of information into and out of memory, all stored for a limited amount of time.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schacter|first=Daniel|title=Psychology Second Edition|origyear=2009|year=2011|publisher=Worth Publishers|location=United States of America|isbn=978-1-4292-3719-2|page=227}}</ref>
{{Main|Baddeley's model of working memory}}
In 1974, [[Alan Baddeley|Baddeley]] and [[Graham Hitch|Hitch]]<ref name="Baddeley Hitch 1974">{{cite book | last1 = Baddeley | first1 = Alan D. | last2 = Hitch | first2 = Graham | title = Working Memory | volume = 2 | editors = Gordon H. Bower | work = The psychology of learning and motivation | publisher = Academic Press | year = 1974 | pages = 47–89 | isbn = 978-0-12-543308-2 |oclc = 777285348 |doi= 10.1016/S0079-7421(08)60452-1}}</ref> introduced and made popular the [[Baddeley's model of working memory|multicomponent model of working memory]]. This theory proposes a [[Baddeley's model of working memory#Central executive|central executive]] that, among other things, is responsible for directing [[attention]] to relevant information, suppressing irrelevant information and inappropriate actions, and for coordinating cognitive processes when more than one task must be done at the same time. The central executive has two "slave systems" responsible for short-term maintenance of information, and a "central executive" is responsible for the supervision of information integration and for coordinating the slave systems. One slave system, the [[phonological loop]] (PL), stores phonological information (that is, the sound of language) and prevents its decay by continuously articulating its contents, thereby refreshing the information in a [[memory rehearsal|rehearsal]] loop. It can, for example, maintain a seven-digit telephone number for as long as one repeats the number to oneself again and again. The other slave system, the [[Baddeley's model of working memory#Visuospatial sketchpad|visuo-spatial sketchpad]], stores visual and spatial information. It can be used, for example, for constructing and manipulating visual images, and for the representation of mental maps. The sketchpad can be further broken down into a visual subsystem (dealing with, for instance, shape, colour, and texture), and a spatial subsystem (dealing with location).
In 2000, Baddeley extended the model by adding a fourth component, the [[Baddeley's model of working memory#Episodic buffer|episodic buffer]], which holds representations that integrate phonological, visual, and spatial information, and possibly information not covered by the slave systems (e.g., semantic information, musical information). The component is episodic because it is assumed to bind information into a unitary episodic representation. The episodic buffer resembles Tulving's concept of [[episodic memory]], but it differs in that the episodic buffer is a temporary store.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://nbu.bg/cogs/events/2002/materials/Markus/ep_bufer.pdf | title=The episodic buffer: a new component of working memory? | author=Baddeley, A. D. | journal=Trends Cogn. Sci. | year=2000 | volume=4 | pages=417–423 | doi=10.1016/S1364-6613(00)01538-2 | pmid=11058819}}</ref>
==Models==
===Feature model===
The feature model was first described by Nairne (1990)<ref name=a /> The primary feature of this model is the use of cues for both short term memory and long term memory. Cues become associated with a memory and can later be used to retrieve memories from long term storage. When a memory is formed, cues associated with the formed memory form a constellation of nerve networks in which the memory is stored. While the cues are present, the nerves that form the constellation are active and the memory is being worked on in short term memory. When the cues are no longer present, the constellation is no longer active and is waiting in long term memory storage for when the cues are once again present. Rather than using the theory of decay for explaining how memories get forgotten, the feature model focuses on item based interference instead. This means that other items that use the same or similar constellations of cues get in the way of remembering other memories. For example, if you are trying to remember a fruit from a list of electronics, you will find that the fruit is easy to recall. Recalling a fruit from a list of other fruit, on the other hand, will prove a far more difficult task. This is the theory behind memory loss used in the feature model.
===OSCAR model===
The Oscillator Based Associative Recallolation (OSCAR) Model was proposed by Browne, Preece and Hulme in 2000 <ref name=b>Brown GDA, Preece T, Hulme C. 2000. Oscillator-based memory for serial order. ''Psychological Review'' 107:127-8.</ref> The OSCAR Model is another cue driven model of memory. In this model, the cues work as a pointer to a memory’s position in the mind. Memories themselves are stored as context vectors on what Brown calls the oscillator part of the theory. While a memory is not being used in short term memory, the context vector oscillates further away from the starting position. When a cue becomes present, the context vector that the cue points to gets oscillated back to the starting point, where the memory can then be used in short term memory. There is no theory of decay in this model, so to account for memory loss or fading the theory states that memories move further and further from the starting point, and retrieval becomes more difficult the further the memory is from the gas station (starting position). Furthermore, some memories oscillate faster than others. The theory behind this is that memories frequently accessed and used will move slower away from the starting point since the probability of the memory being retrieved is relatively high.
==Differences==
Unlike the standard models of short term/working memory, unitary theories do not assume a direct connection between activation level and memory success. They also do not propose role rehearsal, and they focus more on item based interference rather than memory decay.<ref name=c>Nairne, J. (2002) Remembering Over the Short-Term: The Case Against the Standard Model. ''Annu. Rev. Psychol''. 53:53–81</ref> Unitary theories also generally have only one loop or no loop at all, whereas the Working Memory model relies on multiple loops to explain the different forms of memory input. Because of the multiple loop theory, Working Memory has a more difficult time explaining how short term memory gets consolidated into long term memory, whereas the Unitary Theories generally explain long term memory using the same single principle that they use to explain short term memory. On the other hand, Unitary Theories have more trouble explaining situations where short term memory differs such as the word length effect,<ref name=d>Nairne, J., & Neath, I. (1995) Proactive interference plays a role in the word-length effect. ''Psychonomic Bulletin & Review'' December 1997, Volume 4, Issue 4, pp 541-545</ref> which can be more easily explained by the Working Memory model.
==Criticisms ==
The most prevalent criticism of the unitary models is that they try to oversimplify many complex processes into a single mechanism. Studies have shown that short-term memory and long-term memory are two distinct processes that emphasize different levels of activation in the brain among different cortical areas. Furthermore, the rate of decay is much faster in short-term memory as opposed to long-term memory. The OSCAR model in particular does not account for this phenomenon. It also makes an assumption that memories are always circulating to different areas of the brain—never having a definite cortical space that stores the memory. While this transfer of storage is occurring, the rate of decay in the OSCAR model is either constant or non-existent. Both rates are implausible, as a constant rate of decay neglects all external factors that may contribute to a faster rate of decay (e.g. stress, focusing attention on other things). Failing to neglect decay at all is even more implausible as it makes two wrong assertions—memories are not forgotten, and when the information is remembered, it is remembered perfectly every time. While the unitary theories of memory may give attention to alternate factors that the working memory model had initially overlooked, new data has surfaced and the model has adapted to new findings. It is still the standard model of how short-term memory works, and it will continue to be the standard model until new evidence overturns it.
==See also==
*[[Atkinson–Shiffrin memory model]] *[[Attention versus memory in prefrontal cortex]] *[[Fuzzy-trace theory]] *[[Intermediate-term memory]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cognitive psychology]] [[Category:Memory]] [[Category:Psychological theories]]

page.title: World Health Organisation Composite International Diagnostic Interview

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}}
The '''World Health Organisation Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI)''' is a structured interview for psychiatric disorders. As the interview is designed for [[epidemiological studies]], it can be administered by those who are not clinically trained and can be completed in a short amount of time. Versions of the CIDI were used in two important studies, the [[National Comorbidity Survey]] (NCS)<ref name="NCS">{{cite journal |last1=Blazer |first1=DG |last2=Kessler |first2=RC |last3=McGonagle |first3=KA |last4=Swartz |first4=MS |name-list-format=vanc |date=July 1994 |url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/abstract/151/7/979 |url-access=subscription |title=The prevalence and distribution of major depression in a national community sample: The National Comorbidity Survey |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=151 |issue=7 |pages=979-86 |pmid=8010383 |doi=10.1176/ajp.151.7.979 }}</ref> and National Comorbidity Survey Replication (NCS-R)<ref name="NCSR">{{cite journal |last1=Kessler |first1=Ronald C. |last2=Chiu |first2=Wai Tat |last3=Demler |first3=Olga |last4=Merikangas |first4=Kathleen R. |last5=Walters |first5=Ellen E. |name-list-format=vanc |date=June 2005 |url=http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapsychiatry/fullarticle/208671 |title=Prevalence, Severity, and Comorbidity of 12-Month DSM-IV Disorders in the National Comorbidity Survey Replication |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=62 |issue=6 |pages=617-27 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.62.6.617 |doi-access=free |pmid=15939839 |pmc=2847357 }}</ref> which are often used as a reference for estimates of the rates of psychiatric illness in the USA. The first version of the CIDI was published in 1988,<ref name="CIDI">{{cite journal |first1=Lee N. |last1=Robins |first2=John |last2=Wing |first3=Hans Ulrich |last3=Wittchen |first4=John E. |last4=Helzer |first5=Thomas F. |last5=Babor |first6=Jay |last6=Burke |first7=Anne |last7=Farmer |first8=Assen |last8=Jablenski |first9=Roy |last9=Pickens |first10=Darrel A. |last10=Regier |first11=Norman |last11=Sartorius |first12=Leland H. |last12=Towle |name-list-format=vanc |url=http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/45/12/1069 |url-access=subscription |title=The Composite International Diagnostic Interview: An Epidemiologic Instrument Suitable for Use in Conjunction With Different Diagnostic Systems and in Different Cultures |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=45 |issue=12 |pages=1069-1077 |date=December 1988 |pmid=2848472 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1988.01800360017003 }}</ref> and has been periodically updated to reflect the changing diagnostic criteria of [[DSM-IV|DSM]] and [[ICD-10|ICD]].
==Short form== {{Infobox diagnostic | name = WHO Composite International Diagnostic Interview – Short Form | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | synonyms = CIDI-SF | DiseasesDB = <!--{{DiseasesDB2|numeric_id}}--> | ICD10 = <!--{{ICD10|Group|Major|minor|LinkGroup|LinkMajor}} or {{ICD10PCS|code|char1/char2/char3/char4}}--> | ICD9 = | ICDO = | MedlinePlus = <!--article_number--> | eMedicine = <!--article_number--> | MeshID = | OPS301 = <!--{{OPS301|code}}--> | LOINC = {{LOINC|62712-5}} | reference_range = }} The '''Composite International Diagnostic Interview – Short Form''' ('''CIDI-SF''') was first published by [[Ronald C. Kessler]] and colleagues in 1998,<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Ronald C. |last1=Kessler |author1-link=Ronald C. Kessler |first2=Gavin |last2=Andrews |first3=Daniel |last3=Mroczek |first4=Bedirhan |last4=Ustun |first5=Hans-Ulrich |last5=Wittchen |name-list-format=vanc |date=November 1998 |title=The World Health Organization Composite International Diagnostic Interview short-form (CIDI-SF) |journal=International Journal of Methods in Psychiatric Research |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=171-185 |doi=10.1002/mpr.47 |subscription=yes }}</ref> and the [[PhenX Toolkit]] uses this as its adult protocol for general psychiatric assessment.<ref>{{cite web |date=31 January 2017 |title=Protocol Overview: General Psychiatric Assessment - Adult |website=PhenX Toolkit, Ver 20.0 |publisher=RTI International |url=https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/index.php?pageLink=browse.protocoldetails&id=120101 |dead-url=no |archive-date=31 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131155302/https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/index.php?pageLink=browse.protocoldetails&id=120101 }}</ref> However, the CIDI-SF is no longer supported.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hcp.med.harvard.edu/wmhcidi/about-the-who-wmh-cidi/|title=About the WHO WMH-CIDI|last=|first=|date=2017|website=World Mental Health Composite International Diagnostic Interview|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920000344/https://www.hcp.med.harvard.edu/wmhcidi/about-the-who-wmh-cidi/|archive-date=20 September 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=30 March 2018}}</ref> According to a 2007 memo by Kessler, this decision was based on decreased need for the CIDI-SF following the introduction of other short interviews (specifically, [[Patient Health Questionnaire|PRIME-MD]] and [[Mini-international neuropsychiatric interview|MINI]]) and a lack of funding to refine the instrument.<ref name=KesslerMemo2007>{{cite web |last=Kessler |first=Ron |name-list-format=vanc |date=17 August 2007 |title=CIDI-SF Memo |website=World Mental Health Composite International Diagnostic Interview |url=https://www.hcp.med.harvard.edu/wmhcidi/ftpdir_public/CIDI-SF%20memo.pdf |format=PDF |dead-url=no |archive-date=21 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151021065136/http://www.hcp.med.harvard.edu/wmhcidi/ftpdir_public/CIDI-SF%20memo.pdf }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Diagnostic classification and rating scales used in psychiatry]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} <!-- Instructions for adding a footnote: NOTE: Footnotes in this article use names, not numbers. Please see [[Wikipedia:Footnote3]] for details. 1) Assign your footnote a unique name, for example TheSun_Dec9. 2) Add<ref name="TheSun_Dec9"></ref> to the body of the article, where you want the new footnote. 3) Put the reference information (template, mere URL, plain text, e.g.) in between <nowiki><ref name="TheSun_Dec9"> and
</ref></nowiki>. 4) It will appear in the references section immediately PROVIDED YOU HAVE TYPED EVERYTHING CORRECTLY. There is no need to type
anything down here. 5) Multiple footnotes to the same reference will work if you type out, "<nowiki><ref name="TheSun_Dec9"/></nowiki>", again
without the nowiki tags. -->
